definitions.definition: (of a tree or other plant) allow (leaves or fruit) to fall to the ground.
examples: both varieties shed leaves in winter

definitions.definition: (of a reptile, insect, etc.) allow (its skin or shell) to come off, to be replaced by another one that has grown underneath.
examples: slough off, cast off, molt the caterpillar shed its skin

definitions.definition: (of a mammal) lose (hair) as a result of molting, disease, or age.

examples: take off, remove, shrug off, discard, doff, climb out of, slip out of, divest oneself of, peel off we shed our jackets
what they lacked was a willingness to shed the arrogance of the past

definitions.definition: have the property of preventing (something) from being absorbed.
examples: this leather has a superior ability to shed water, sweat, and salt

definitions.definition: eliminate part of (an electrical power load) by disconnecting circuits.
